items.message:
River levels are forecast to rise at the Little Alne gauge as a result of expected heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible tomorrow Saturday 19/10/2024. We expect flooding to affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Arrow between Studley and Salford Priors and the River Alne between Bird in Hand and Alcester on the River Alne including farmland and caravan parks. We are issuing this flood alert as a precautionary measure.
Further is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by tomorrow afternoon Saturday 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

River levels are currently falling on the River Avon but are expected to rise tomorrow morning in response to tonights rainfall. Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible but property flooding is not expected.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. 
Further rainfall, sometimes heavy, is forecast over the weekend. River levels are expected to rise again in response to this.
We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further Flood Alerts or Warnings if necessary.
Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
To check the status of road closures online, please visit the One Network live map.
This message will be updated by 09:00 tomorrow morning, 19/10/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Hundred Foot Washes in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk

floodArea.riverOrSea: Old Bedford River, New Bedford River, Hundred Foot Drain, River Delph

items.message:
River levels are falling but remain responsive to further rainfall. This information is correct as of 3:15pm on Friday 18 October. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 1 centimetre of water on the road. Flood water is receding from the causeway at Welney. There are currently no issues on the Earith causeway. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places.
The Environment Agency are liaising with Cambridgeshire Highways and Norfolk Highways, who will decide whether to close the roads. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency.
We will update this message by 8am tomorrow, 19/10/2024.

items.message:
River levels are high on the Lower River Colne and Frays River today, Friday 18th October.

No property flooding is expected, but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads, particularly in the Thorney Mill Road and Cricketfield Road areas, which may impact Riverside Mobile Home Park.

Some heavy rain is possible overnight and into tomorrow, Saturday 19th October. River levels are expected to rise slowly on the Lower Colne at our Staines Moor river gauge. 

We are continuing to monitor rainfall and river levels and will remove this alert when the risk has reduced.

Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses, and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.

This message will be updated by 6pm on Saturday 19th October, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from now, 5pm Friday 18th October, and over the weekend. Water levels are expected to continue to rise gradually. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry Road in Horning. Water levels are forecast to continue to slowly rise through the weekend, influenced by the current set of high spring tides. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9pm tomorrow, Saturday 19th October.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The River Yeo level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 8.42 m and is falling. The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 7.20 m and is stable. Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the road from Muchelney to Long Load above 7.86m, the road from Muchelney to Thorney above 7.93m and the road from Muchelney to Draycott, Law Lane, above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels

Further rainfall is forecast late on Friday evening and through the early hours of Saturday morning. The weekend will remain unsettled.

The situation is being continually monitored and staff are checking the condition of flood banks, spillways and weed screens. This message will be updated by 2 PM on 19th October or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Flooding is possible from Friday evening into Saturday morning as rivers remain high following recent rain, with further rain forecast into the weekend.
Catchments are wet and rivers are expected to remain high, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads into the weekend.
Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions. Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. We are constantly monitoring river levels.
This message will be updated on Saturday, or earlier if the situation changes.

River levels have peaked and are falling, although are forecast to rise at the Titley Mill river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall, and are expected to peak at 03:45 on 19/10/2024. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. 

We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Arrow from Michaelchurch to Brierley. Other areas that may be affected include Kington, Staunton and Eardisland. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high today 18/10/2024. 

We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 9am on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Heavy rain is expected tonight, and rising river levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible when river levels are at their highest between 11:00 PM and 4:00 AM tonight. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, and Doniford Stream.

Weather conditions are expected to improve tomorrow, before a further band of rain arrives early on Sunday. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, and staff have been clearing debris from weed screens and checking rivers for blockages.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Heavy rain is expected tonight, and rising river levels may lead to flooding.

Flooding of roads and low lying land is possible as rivers react to the rain which is forecast between 11:00 PM and 4:00 AM tonight. Property flooding is not expected. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Tone, Hillfarrance Brook, Halsewater Stream, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around roads around Hillfarrance, Bradford on Tone, Lane End Road at Ham and the Creech St Michael to Henlade road. Bradford on Tone ringbanks will be bankfull.

Weather conditions are expected to improve on Saturday, before a further band of rain arrives early on Sunday. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels, and staff have been clearing debris from weed screens and checking rivers for blockages.

Please monitor local water levels and weather conditions, and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides and high river flows.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.90mAOD at 04:15 on and 4.95mAOD at 16:15 on Saturday 19th October 2024.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 142 cubic metres per second and is steady. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next five days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on Saturday 19th October, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light North Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.07 m. The total forecast tide is 6.31 metres Chart Datum (3.26 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high tide, small amounts of water will flood land and fields at Climping. Waves will overtop the sea front, directing water westwards along Mill Lane (from the right of the East car park) towards properties on Climping Street. Water may pond near property and in Climping Street Car Park. Sunday's early morning tide at 01:45 20/10/2024 is forecast to be 4 cm lower (3.22 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024.The highest tide ahead is forecast at 14:00 on Sunday 20/10/2024 (3.34 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast and routinely check the condition of the beach at Climping. Avoid walking at the sea front or parking at Climping Street Car Park. Access could be restricted during and after high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 19/10/2024.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are high but starting to fall on the Lower River Loddon following recent heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue, especially in the Sindlesham area. 

Further rainfall is forecast this evening and overnight (18/10/24), and is expected to be heavy at times. River levels will be responsive to further rainfall and may rise again. We are monitoring the situation. Our staff are checking and clearing trash screens. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 19/10/24, or as the situation changes.

This alert remains in force as high tides tomorrow morning may lead to flooding along the North Sea Coast in Yorkshire.  Flooding is possible around the high tide between 5:30 AM and 6:45 AM on Saturday 19/10/2024.  Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads near the coast, including Bridlington. Further flooding is possible over the weekend due to higher-than-normal tides and this alert may be re-issued as a result. We are closely monitoring the situation. Stay away from beaches, promenades, footpaths, and roads in, as waves and spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 9:00 PM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:00 on 19/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light North Westerly Force 4 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.09 m. The total forecast tide is 5.26 metres Chart Datum (2.52 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. For 1 hour either side of high water, the tide will flood Shore Road. At Bosham High Street, water will be near to or will flood front door steps. Gardens or land of shore side properties around the Harbour could also be affected. Sunday's early morning tide at 01:45 20/10/2024 is forecast to be 9 cm lower (2.43 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024. The highest tide ahead is forecast on Sunday 20/10/2024 (2.59 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have them, please install flood boards 1 hour before high tide. Avoid walking through flood water as it may contain hidden hazards and be deep in places. We will update this message by 18:00 on 19/10/2024.

River levels are currently falling however further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours which will see levels rise again at the Byton and Butts Bridge river gauges as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads to the River Lugg north of Leominster. Locations that may be affected include Yarpole, Mortimers Cross, Kingsland and the B4362. 

 We expect river levels to remain high in the coming days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Plymouth Sound, Wembury Bay and tidal estuaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding is possible over the high tide on Friday evening. High water at Plymouth is at 7:13pm, times of high water will vary along the coast.
Spring tides peak on Friday evening and are forecast to cause flooding between 6:13pm and 8:13pm.
Locations mostly at risk are low lying areas of Plymouth Sound and along the estuaries.
Waterside locations along the estuary may be flooded. Do not walk or drive through flood water.
Tide levels are lower for Saturdayâs high tides, however, flooding to low lying land and roads is still possible and a flood alert remains in force.
Unsettled weather conditions are expected to cause further flooding over Sunday morningâs high tide; flood warnings will be issued where required.
We are monitoring the situation and will update this information by 11am on Saturday, or if the situation changes.
Detailed tidal information; the forecast high tide level at Plymouth is 2.96m AOD. Expect tide levels along the coast to be between 0.1 and 0.2m above tide table level. Force 5 southerly winds and offshore wave heights of up to 2m are forecast over the high tide.

items.description: Tidal areas of Littlehampton Rope Walk
items.message: Saturday afternoon's tide at 13:15 on 19/10/2024 is higher than normal due to unsettled weather with light Southerly Force 2 winds. The weather increases tide table values by 0.07 m. The total forecast tide is 6.31 metres Chart Datum (3.26 mAOD) at Littlehampton. For 2 hours either side of high water, the tide could cause flooding to boatyards and the industrial areas along Littlehampton Rope Walk. Water will be high up slipways and could be forced up through drains causing minor flooding to roads. If the tide is slightly higher than forecast, following flood damage in April 2024, it could be possible for a small amount of water to flow through The Shipyard, and onto Rope Walk. Sunday's early morning tide at 01:45 20/10/2024 is forecast to be 4 cm lower (3.22 mAOD). Similar flood impacts are expected to continue until Monday 21/10/2024. The highest tide ahead is forecast on Sunday 20/10/2024 (3.34 mAOD). We continue to monitor the forecast. If you have it, please install flood protection 2 hours before high tide. We will update this message by 18:00 on 19/10/2024.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message:
High spring tides are forecast over the coming days. The first forecast high water is 20:45 BST on 18/10/2024 with a level of 8.04 mAOD and a Force 5 Southerly wind. The second forecast high water is 09:00 BST on 19/10/2024 with a level of 7.76 mAOD and a Force 2 Westerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide. 
There is a possibility of high water levels for the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.  
This is forecast to be the highest tide, but further high tides are expected throughout the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further alerts and warnings if necessary. 
Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches, promenades and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. 
This message will be updated by 2pm on Saturday 19th October 2024 or as the situation changes.

The first forecast high water is at 20:00PM on 18/10/2024 with a level of 1.44mAODN with Southerly force 6 winds. items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 7am and 9am, tomorrow, Saturday 19th October. We expect to see water on roads and paths to beaches and on the quays in Brancaster, Burnham Overy, Holkham, Wells and Blakeney. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Wells of 3.63 mAODN at 8am, Saturday 19th October, which is 0.04m above tide tables, wind Force 4, South-Easterly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 12pm, Saturday 19th October.

items.message: A high tide of 4.94m AOD is expected at Richmond at around 3.30pm on Friday 18th October and a second high tide of 4.91m AOD at 04.30am on Saturday 19th October. Due to high river flows coming down the River Crane, the Crane Tidal Gates may not be able to close to hold back the incoming tide from the River Thames. As a result, the incoming tide may flow up the River Crane which, when combined with the river flow already in the channel, could lead to high river levels. Some flooding of gardens and low lying land is expected for a short period of time either side of high tide. We do not expect any flooding to properties. We will be monitoring river and tide levels and will update or remove this message before the high tide at 4.30pm on Saturday 19th October.

A Flood Alert for the Tidal River Aire Catchment remains in force today, Friday 18th October 2024.

Areas most at risk include the River Aire from Haddlesey Weir to Airmyn. 

This alert will remain in force for a series of high spring tides in the coming days and applies especially to morning tides. The tidal levels will gradually drop off as we go through the weekend.

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at London Bridge is 4.45mAOD at 03:30 and 4.50mAOD at 15:30 on Saturday 19th October 2024.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Custom House (EC3R), Narrow Street (E14), Mayflower and Angel pubs (SE16), Royal Naval College riverfront, the Almshouse Slipway at Crane Street (SE10), Bankside by the Tate Modern (SE1), and Three Mill Island (E3).

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 145 cubic metres per second and is falling slowly. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 19:00 on Saturday 19th October 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Severn Ham, Tewkesbury
items.message:
River levels continue to rise at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property, roads and farmland remains possible.  We expect flooding to affect properties and roads in and around Severn Ham, Tewkesbury. 

Predicted Peak: Mythe 4.2m to 4.5m on Sunday 20/10/24. 

Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to rise further and remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  

This message will be updated by 10am on Saturday 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Avon at Pill and Shirehampton, Watch House Road and Station Road areas
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding this evening.
Highest tide level is expected to be at Watch House Road in Pill and the Station Road area in Shirehampton at 8:45 PM BST on 18/10/2024. The forecast high water is expected to reach a level of 8.04 mAOD with a Force 5 Southerly wind. Flooding is possible two hours either side of this time.
Areas most at risk include Watch House Road in Pill and the Station Road area in Shirehampton.
This is the highest Spring tide. Further high tides are expected throughout the weekend but these are not expected to meet the flood warning criteria. 
Our incident response staff will be on site closing flood gates. Be careful along beaches, promenades and low lying coastal footpaths and roads. 
Refer to local authority website for road closures.
This message will be updated by 2pm on Saturday 19th October 2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Somerset coast at Portishead and Portbury Dock, seafront properties and Portbury Dock areas
items.message:
High tides are expected to cause flooding this evening.

The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is for a peak level at Avonmouth of 8.04 mAODN at 8:45 PM on 18/10/2024, which is 0.22 m above tide tables, with southerly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.)

Areas most at risk include the coastline between Portishead Point and Avonmouth including Portishead Ashlands Nature Reserve and the Royal Portbury Dock.

Tidal conditions are expected to improve over the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.

Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
High tides this evening may lead to flooding. 
The forecast high water is 20:45 BST on 18/10/2024 with a level of 8.04 mAOD and a Force 5 Southerly wind. Times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.
Areas most at risk include the Severn Estuary at Oldbury-on-Severn, Northwick and Avonmouth including Aust and Old Passage.
No property flooding is expected.
This is the highest Spring tide. Further high tides are expected throughout the weekend but these are not expected to meet the flood alert criteria. 
We are closely monitoring the situation and checking flood defences.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 2:00 PM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Rising river levels are expected to cause flooding throughout the afternoon.
Flooding is expected when river levels are at their highest from 3:00 PM on 18/10/2024.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Pumped Watercourses at Preesall, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around land drained by the pumped watercourses in Preesall including properties contained by Pilling Lane, Green Dick's Lane, Head Dyke Lane and Lancaster Road and those accessed from Grasmere Road.
Weather conditions are expected to improve overnight and no further flooding is expected.
We are deploying pumps, people and equipment and monitoring rainfall and river levels.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses.
This message will be updated by 8:30 PM on 18/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Higher than normal tides are expected to cause flooding overnight.

Highest tide level is expected to be at 12:30 AM on 19/10/2024. Flooding is possible several hours either side of this time.

Areas most at risk include Roa Island, Rampside, A5087 coast road, Aldingham, South Ulverston, Canal Foot, Greenodd, Cark, West Plain Farm, Grange-over-Sands, Meathop, Milnthorpe, B5282 coast road, Sandside and Arnside.

High tides on Saturday 19/10/2024 will remain above the Flood Alert level but we do not expect to need to issue a further Flood Warning. However, a combination of spring tides, strong winds and low pressure on Sunday may lead to further Flood Warnings being issued on the 20/10/2024. 

We have closed flood gates at Arnside promenade.
 
Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. Please don't put yourself or others at risk.
 
This message will be updated by 9:00 AM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Higher than normal tides are expected to cause flooding overnight.
Highest tide level is expected to be at homes, farms and businesses in Glasson, Thurnham Moss and Cockerham including the B5290, Conder Side Caravan Park, Moss Lane, Hillam Lane and Marsh Lane at 12:42 AM on 19/10/2024. Flooding is possible 2 hours either side of this time.

We do not expect to see similar impacts from the high tide tomorrow afternoon.
Refer to local authority website for road closures. The A588 Lancaster Road and B5290 at Conder Green may be flooded during high tides.
This message will be updated by 8:00 AM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Dee Estuary from Parkgate to Chester
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast overnight, 19/10/2024.
Flooding is possible at low lying lands and roads from 12:30 AM on 19/10/2024 at Chester, peaking around 1:15 AM
We do not currently anticipate the Flood Alert level to be met during any of the following high tides in the current sequence.
This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal River Dee from Grosvenor Bridge to the Groves

This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 19/10/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Severn at Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn
items.message:

We expect flooding to affect Hanley Road, Upton upon Severn. Predicted Peak:- Saxons Lode 4.8m to 5.2m on Saturday morning, 19/10/24.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days.
